She&#8217;s lived with my two aunts for as long as I can remember. Growing up, I don&#8217;t recall having any long, meaningful talks with my grandfather. One of the few things I do remember is a statement I overheard him telling my mother when I was a little girl: &#8220;Why are you spending so much money on her education? She&#8217;s only going to run off to get married when she turns eighteen.&#8221; I was told that sons were prized because they carry on the family name. Daughters… Well, they&#8217;re just &#8220;guests.&#8221; It&#8217;s how traditions are, and I understood not to ask certain questions.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/a_sissie-chang_dtayd/'><img width=\"2100\" height=\"1400\" src=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/A_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?fit=2100%2C1400&#38;ssl=1\" class=\"attachment-full size-full\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/A_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?w=2100&#38;ssl=1 2100w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/A_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?resize=170%2C113&#38;ssl=1 170w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/A_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?resize=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1 800w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/A_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?resize=768%2C512&#38;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/A_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?resize=1024%2C683&#38;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/A_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?w=1600&#38;ssl=1 1600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" data-attachment-id=\"69076\" data-permalink=\"https://www.burnmagazine.org/a_sissie-chang_dtayd/\" data-orig-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/A_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?fit=2100%2C1400&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"2100,1400\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;Sissie Chang&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;\\u00a9 2019 Sissie Chang. data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;Sissie Chang&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;\\u00a9 2019 Sissie Chang.  All rights reserved.&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"D_Sissie Chang_DTAYD\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/D_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?fit=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/D_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?fit=800%2C534&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>My grandparents had three daughters, and like the most traditional Chinese families, they continued having children until sons were born. As my grandfather&#8217;s health declined, his second and third daughters—both retired, unwed, and living under the same roof—were his primary caregivers. These same two daughters continue to take care of my grandmother today.</p>\n<p>Meanwhile, a few time zones away, I&#8217;m suddenly living back at home, taking care of my own mother as she undergoes cancer treatment. It&#8217;s funny, none of us have run off yet. We&#8217;re still here.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/p_sissie-chang_dtayd/'><img width=\"2100\" height=\"1400\" src=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/P_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?fit=2100%2C1400&#38;ssl=1\" class=\"attachment-full size-full\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/P_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?w=2100&#38;ssl=1 2100w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/P_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?resize=170%2C113&#38;ssl=1 170w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/P_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?resize=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1 800w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/P_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?resize=768%2C512&#38;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/P_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?resize=1024%2C683&#38;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/P_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?w=1600&#38;ssl=1 1600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" data-attachment-id=\"69091\" data-permalink=\"https://www.burnmagazine.org/p_sissie-chang_dtayd/\" data-orig-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/P_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?fit=2100%2C1400&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"2100,1400\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;Sissie Chang&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;\\u00a9 2019 Sissie Chang. All rights reserved.&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"U_Sissie Chang_DTAYD\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/U_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?fit=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/U_Sissie-Chang_DTAYD.jpg?fit=800%2C534&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>As the years passed, I watched the prized sons of the family become more and more distant, and I couldn&#8217;t help but start to question that notion about daughters being unimportant. <span class=\"Apple-converted-space\"> </span></p>\n<p>I guess my grandfather was wrong. Don&#8217;t throw away your daughters.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<div>\n<h3>Short Bio</h3>\n</div>\n<div>\n<p>Sissie Chang is a documentary photographer based out of Orange County, California. At one time, she was a firm believer that the most intriguing stories, and those with the best backdrops, required a passport. She eventually discovered that the most engaging human stories are actually the ones you see on a daily basis.</p>\n<p>Her first self-published book, <i>Don’t throw away your daughters,</i> is slated for release Spring 2020.</p>\n</div>\n<div> </div>\n<div>\n<h3>Related Links</h3>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.sissiechang.com\"><span style=\"color: #000000; font-family: arial, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11-Patriotism-And-Romanticism-Studies-Järnefelt-1928-8987ea2d-bef6-43dc-b892-664652102656.jpg?w=1600&#38;ssl=1 1600w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11-Patriotism-And-Romanticism-Studies-Järnefelt-1928-8987ea2d-bef6-43dc-b892-664652102656.jpg?w=2400&#38;ssl=1 2400w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\" /></h4>\n<h4 class=\"sc-jbKcbu ftkFFW\">Jaakko Kahilaniemi</h4>\n</div>\n<h2>100 Hectares of Understanding</h2>\n<h5>[ EPF 2019 FINALIST ]</h5>\n<p>It’s impossible to overstate the significance of forests for Finland, both historically and economically. 71,6 % of the total area of the country is covered by forests – that’s over 26 million hectares. I own 100 hectares. <em>100 Hectares of Understanding</em> is my attempt to understand the forest area I inherited 1997. Throughout adulthood my relationship with the forest has been somewhat discordant and attitude towards my inheritance has been indifferent. Recent explorations in the forest, and in the world of forestry have managed to provoke my interest towards unfamiliar inherited property of mine. I study what nature has to offer to urbanized people and I will try to create new ways of thinking and ways to experience and feel the forest. I capture nature through my lens before applying the alchemical process that makes art out of the familiar. I arbitrarily mix various types of pictures with each other, and define them as part of a larger visual entity. I am working with the method of deconstruction, but rather than creating physical work out of the results of my private rituals in the forest, I unveil the result through the medium of photography. For the unknown to become familiar requires both physical and delicate acts: to nurture and to tame, to master and to yield. My photographs are testimonial, traces of my aspirations towards understanding and awareness. Photography, for me, is a gateway to the very core of my thoughts and imagination. II see similarities between my acts in the forest and walking artist Hamish Fultons walks, which he records with photographs and poems. Taking inspiration from Fluxus and the traditions of Arte Povera, I seek to encounter the forest with a playful and open approach. <em>100 Hectares of Understanding</em> consists of the objects that I’ve found, the acts that I’ve photographed, the sculptures I’ve made and visual secrets that I have created.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a data-orig-size=\"4500,2471\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;8&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;Jaakko Kahilaniemi&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;NIKON D810&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;Jaakko Kahilaniemi Photography&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1439407763&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;Jaakko Kahilaniemi Photography&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"Jaakko Kahilaniemi Photography\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1-100-Planted-Saviors-of-the-Heritage-95016342-8c48-4a3c-846c-e244a657215e.jpg?fit=800%2C439&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1-100-Planted-Saviors-of-the-Heritage-95016342-8c48-4a3c-846c-e244a657215e.jpg?fit=800%2C439&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h3>Short Bio</h3>\n<div class=\"sc-RefOD kyWBYY\">\n<div class=\"sc-cqpYsc iCVdLz\">\n<p class=\"sc-fQejPQ gxlmwq Paragraph-sc-972wlj-0 cOTQqy\">Kahilaniemi was born in 1989 in Finland. He earned his BA in Photography from Turku Arts Academy (FI) in 2014 and his MA also in photography from Aalto University, the School of Arts, Design and Architecture (FI) in 2018. Kahilaniemi is a recipient of the ING Unseen Talent Award (NL, 2018) and the Backlight Price (FI, 2017). He got chosen as one of the eight finalists for the Tokyo International Photo Contest in 2019. Kahilaniemi was one of the selected Lens Culture Emerging Talents in 2017, and he also was one of the ten finalists in Hyéres Photo Festival and in Fotofestiwal Łódź in 2018. Kahilaniemi has exhibited at Denver Art Museum the US, Voies Off Arles, Benaki Museum Athens, Klompching Gallery NYC, Robert Capa Center in Hungary, FOTOFLUSS Wolkersdorf, Fotografisk Center Copenhagen, Tampere Art Museum, Organ Vida Festival Zagreb, , Unseen Amsterdam, Noorderlicht Photofestival, Northern Photography Center Oulu 33rd Festival de Photographie Hyères, Fotofestiwal Łódź, Kunsthalle Memmingen, Kunstverein Ludwigshafen, Potentiale Festival Austria, OFF_Festival, Photo Is:rael, the Latvian Museum of Photography, the Finnish Museum of Photography, Kunst Haus Wien and others. Kahilaniemi’s work has been featured in many publications, including Fisheye Magazine, Das Magazin, Eikon Magazine, Europe Now Journal, Fotografi Norway, GUP magazine, Greenpeace Magazine, Der Greif and HANT Magazine.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n<aside class=\"sc-iQKALj lowtCN\">\n<div class=\"sc-bwCtUz jmIOcX\" title=\"Daniel Kovalovszky\"> </div>\n</aside>\n<h3>Related Links</h3>\n<p><a 2400a2d.jpg?fit=3375%2C4500&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn7@2020_3/2020/08/25/01-16-25-025_f3cf30e80cad57ca.webp","https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/9-Preserving-Nature-dc360e3e-9f86-47b1-a603-03968a068e64.jpg?fit=3375%2C4500&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn96@2020_6/2020/08/25/01-16-36-677_22f72362201033a0.webp","https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/10-Colliding-Generations-3c414bd4-b27f-47e4-929f-ed36f3df848c.jpg?fit=4500%2C1918&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn31@2020_1/2020/08/25/01-16-35-787_ca319642f39195dc.webp","https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1-100-Planted-Saviors-of-the-Heritage-95016342-8c48-4a3c-846c-e244a657215e.jpg?fit=4500%2C2471&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn31@2020_6/2020/08/25/01-16-33-141_c42b65b89f6e228c.webp","https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/magnumfoundation.png?resize=202%2C82":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn91@2020_3/2020/08/25/01-16-34-378_f5de62f6d0112576.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598318178419},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 The Mountain of Guerrero has been a territory without law. dozens of persons has moved to other places to live.Located on Mexico\\u2019s southern Pacific Coast, is home to most of the poppy bulbs that yield heroin consumed in the U.S.The United Nations estimates that Mexico has the world\\u2019s third-largest geographic area dedicated to illicit opium cultivation, after Afghanistan and Myanmar. Guerrero Mexico on February 15th 2015.&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1425057738&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;\\u00a9 Yael Mart\\u00ednez&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;24&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;8000&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0.00625&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;Burning man&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"Burning man\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-001.jpg?fit=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-001.jpg?fit=800%2C534&#38;ssl=1\" class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-70256\" src=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-001.jpg?resize=800%2C533&#038;ssl=1\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"533\" srcset=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-001.jpg?w=2100&#38;ssl=1 2100w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-001.jpg?resize=170%2C113&#38;ssl=1 170w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-001.jpg?resize=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1 800w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-001.jpg?resize=768%2C512&#38;ssl=1 768w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-001.jpg?resize=1024%2C683&#38;ssl=1 1024w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-001.jpg?w=1600&#38;ssl=1 1600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\" /></h3>\n<h3>Yael Martinez</h3>\n</div>\n<h2>La casa que sangra (The house that bleeds)</h2>\n<p>It was getting dark when I got the call. Luz, my wife, was telling me that they had killed her brother Beto. She was uncontrollable — I had never heard her speak like that. Her voice was shaking, breaking. I could not sleep all night. &#8220;Beto was killed, hanged,&#8221; resonated in my head, &#8220;he was beaten, burned, but they told us that he committed suicide.” Her other brothers, David and Nacho, had been missing for over 3 months.<span class=\"Apple-converted-space\"> </span></p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/07/yael-martinez/attachment/yael-martinez-002/'><img width=\"2100\" height=\"1400\" src=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-002.jpg?fit=2100%2C1400&#38;ssl=1\" class=\"attachment-full size-full\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-002.jpg?w=2100&#38;ssl=1 2100w, https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-002.jpg?w=1600&#38;ssl=1 1600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" data-attachment-id=\"70257\" data-orig-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-002.jpg?fit=2100%2C1400&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"2100,1400\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;16&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;Yael Martinez V.&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;Canon EOS 6D&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1478080137&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;28&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;1600&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0.005&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"Yael Martinez-002\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-002.jpg?fit=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1\" data-image-title=\"Yael Martinez-008\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-008.jpg?fit=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-008.jpg?fit=800%2C534&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/07/yael-martinez/attachment/empty/'><img width=\"2100\" height=\"1399\" src=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-009.jpg?fit=2100%2C1399&#38;ssl=1\" class=\"attachment-full size-full\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-009.jpg?w=2100&#38;ssl=1 2100w, https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-009.jpg?resize=170%2C113&#38;ssl=1 170w, https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-009.jpg?resize=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1 800w, https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-009.jpg?resize=768%2C512&#38;ssl=1 768w, https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-009.jpg?resize=1024%2C682&#38;ssl=1 1024w, https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-009.jpg?w=1600&#38;ssl=1 1600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" data-attachment-id=\"70264\" data-permalink=\"https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/07/yael-martinez/attachment/empty/\" data-orig-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-009.jpg?fit=2100%2C1399&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"2100,1399\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;5&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;Yael Martinez V.&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;Canon EOS 6D&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;(my wife) &#38; Me at home after the lose of her Brother Beto. Taxco Guerrero M\\u00e9xico.\\r   Guerrero is one of the Mexican States that have been most affected by organized crime; It is the second poorest and most violent state in the country. The condition of social and economic marginalization of Guerrero is becoming more evident. The crisis of the rule of law is increasingly alarming and forced disappearances are only one of the symptoms that prove it. In 2013, three of my brothers-in-law died. (They used to live in Iguala, the place from where the Ayotzinapa students disappeared). One of them was killed; the other two disappeared.) After these events I began documenting my family, and the families of other missing people, in order to capture in photographs the psychological and emotional breakdown caused by the loss of family members, especially for parents, children, and siblings. I am working with the concepts of pain, emptiness, absence, and forgetting.&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1381743726&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;\\u00a9 Yael Mart\\u00ednez&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;24&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;400&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0.01&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;Empty&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"Empty\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-009.jpg?fit=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-009.jpg?fit=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>After these events in 2013, I began to document my family and the families of other missing people as well as fractured communities that are immerse in violence in Mexico; I am trying to create work that represents the connection between absence and presence, and this state of invisibility in a symbolic manner, working with the concepts of pain, emptiness, absence, and forgetting. The symbolic construction of the territory where violence penetrate all and this violence crosses the physical and spiritual space of those who inhabit it. The territory as an analogy to a body / space that can be a house, a person, a family, a community or a country.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/07/yael-martinez/attachment/ruined-house/'><img width=\"2100\" height=\"1400\" src=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-010.jpg?fit=2100%2C1400&#38;ssl=1\" class=\"attachment-full size-full\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-010.jpg?w=2100&#38;ssl=1 2100w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-010.jpg?resize=170%2C113&#38;ssl=1 170w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-010.jpg?resize=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1 800w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-010.jpg?resize=768%2C512&#38;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-010.jpg?resize=1024%2C683&#38;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-010.jpg?w=1600&#38;ssl=1 1600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" data-attachment-id=\"70265\" data-permalink=\"https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/07/yael-martinez/attachment/ruined-house/\" data-orig-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-010.jpg?fit=2100%2C1400&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"2100,1400\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;9&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;Yael Martinez V.&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;Canon EOS 6D&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;Ruined house in the comunity of Santiago Temixco, Guerrero Mexico.In 2013 we lose 3 brothers-in laws. One of them was found killed at jail. Two of them still disappear. They used to live at Iguala Guerrero, the same place where the Ayotzinapa students disappeared. After that event happened we went to some places where some traces were found. We did not found anything. Guerrero Mexico on December 14,2014&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1418569388&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;\\u00a9 Yael data-permalink=\"https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/07/yael-martinez/attachment/broken/\" data-orig-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-012.jpg?fit=2100%2C1399&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"2100,1399\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;4&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;Yael Martinez V.&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;Canon EOS 6D&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;Digno Cruz (My grand-father-in-law) was crying at home while he was talking about his  missing grandsons. Guerrero Mexico. The discovery of several mass graves during the search of the 43 normalistas Ayotzinapa, Guerrero, shows the magnitude of the crisis of enforced disappearances in the country. The goverment have found 60 clandestine graves in the cities of Iguala-Taxco with at least 129 bodies (20 women and 109 men). None of them belonged to the 43 normalistas missing in Iguala during the month of September 2014. Official figures show that in recent years there have been 30 000  disappearances and Guerrero is one of the Mexican States that have been most affected. data-permalink=\"https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/07/yael-martinez/attachment/eye-2/\" data-orig-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-020.jpg?fit=2100%2C1400&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"2100,1400\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;3.2&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;Yael Martinez V.&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;Canon EOS 6D&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;My daugther Itzel Mart\\u00ednez at home in Taxco Guerrero.She is 9 years old.\\rIn 2013  three of my  brothers in-laws died. After these events I began documenting my family and tried to capture the psychological and emotional breakdown caused by the loss of a family member.Guerrero Mexico on February 18, 2019&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1550529452&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;100&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;6400&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0.016666666666667&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;eye&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"eye\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-020.jpg?fit=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-020.jpg?fit=800%2C534&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<div>\n<h3>Bio</h3>\n</div>\n<div>\n<div id=\"u8453-19\" class=\"clearfix grpelem shared_content\" data-muse-temp-textcontainer-sizepolicy=\"true\" data-muse-temp-textcontainer-pinning=\"true\" data-muse-uid=\"U8453\" data-muse-type=\"txt_frame\" data-ibe-flags=\"txtStyleSrc\" data-content-guid=\"u8453-19_content\">\n<p>Martínez is based in Guerrero, Mexico. His work has explored the connections between, poverty, narcotraffic, organized crime, and how this affects the communities in his native Guerrero in southern Mexico. He is trying to represent the relationship of absence and presence and this state of invisibility in a symbolic manner working with the concepts of pain, emptiness, absence, and forgetting.</p>\n<p>He received the Magnum Emergency Fund, Magnum On religión, and was named one of the PDN&#8217;s 30 new and emerging photographers to watch 2017. In 2015 he was selected in the Joop Joop Swart Master Class Latinoamerica. He was a finalist in the Eugene Smith grant in 2015 and 2016. He was nominated to the Foam Paul Huf Award, the Prix Pictet and the Infinity award of the ICP.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div>\n<h3>Related Links</h3>\n</div>\n<div>\n<p><a ds/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-010.jpg?fit=2100%2C1400&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn47@2020_5/2020/08/25/01-16-32-498_c0449a68e575bad1.webp","https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-011.jpg?fit=2100%2C1400&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn55@2020_1/2020/08/25/01-16-31-103_e60705153bb1351d.webp","https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-012.jpg?fit=2100%2C1399&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn55@2020_2/2020/08/25/01-16-22-883_8262f182cd467df1.webp","https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-013.jpg?fit=2100%2C1400&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn27@2020_5/2020/08/25/01-16-26-872_77851cd4ee16c211.webp","https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-014.jpg?fit=2100%2C1399&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn44@2020_4/2020/08/25/01-16-35-224_8dc3cb5ebf09a814.webp","https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-015.jpg?fit=2100%2C1400&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn41@2020_6/2020/08/25/01-16-38-840_0f2be6ec881f1742.webp","https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-016.jpg?fit=2100%2C1400&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn19@2020_5/2020/08/25/01-16-37-995_6810bba3600d980a.webp","https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-017.jpg?fit=2100%2C1399&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn82@2020_3/2020/08/25/01-16-35-634_360d6495faf204af.webp","https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-018.jpg?fit=2100%2C1400&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn56@2020_4/2020/08/25/01-16-21-047_54b798c961915eb0.webp","https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Yael-Martinez-019.jpg?fit=2100%2C1400&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/m /></a></h4>\n<h4>Alexander Bronfer</h4>\n<h2>Floating</h2>\n<p>This project is about the tight bonds connecting us to The Dead Sea, in the face of ecological catastrophe threatening the future of this unique natural treasure.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/48749801158_18471b25ff_o/'><img width=\"1024\" height=\"684\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"48750318852_5b5e9bda23_o (1)\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/48750318852_5b5e9bda23_o-1.jpg?fit=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/48750318852_5b5e9bda23_o-1.jpg?fit=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>People are always fascinated by the Dead Sea. This place was always a refuge for messiahs, zealots, martyrs, kings, and ascetics. People prayed, sinned, healed and kill each other on these yellowish shores. They built dams and plants, drilled wells, cut the sea from any source of freshwater and left it to die. And meanwhile, we continue praying, sinningand killing each other, moving our beach chairs and sunshades deeper and deeper, silently following the disappearing sea</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a data-medium-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/48749802858_036b8552e3_o-1.jpg?fit=800%2C534&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/48749802858_036b8552e3_o-1.jpg?fit=800%2C534&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h3>Short Bio</h3>\n<p>Alexander Bronfer is an Israeli photographer. Born in Ukraine and studied in Saint Petersburg (Russia). His main interest is the connection between street and fine art photography. After arriving to Israel, Alexander lived in Kibutz in South Israel where he fell in love with the Dead Sea region.  He is a finalist of multiple international and Israeli photography festivals. Recently he spends a good amount of time on personal projects mainly in Israel and Eastern Europe. </p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h3>Related Links</h3>\n<p><a class=\"wp-caption-text\">At first, we bought some food, I’m a stocker by nature so I already had most of the food in that picture.</p></div></p>\n<h4 class=\"sc-jbKcbu ftkFFW\">Irina Werning</h4>\n</div>\n<h2>La Cuarentena</h2>\n<p>It’s the new normal ! Lockdowns are being championed as a solution to the spread of the number one enemy: the coronavirus. In developing countries like Argentina, where 40% of the population lives in poverty, it’s difficult to just stay fixated on the fear of infection when one realizes how daunting the economic setback of these strict lockdown policies are for most of the population. In these economies so many more workers carry out hands-on work which is incompatible with the new moral high ground of social distancing. So many more are also likely to be employed informally and thus are clinging to cash payments in exchange for the type of daily work which the government has black-listed and penalized. It’s hard to buy much time with lower income and lower saving or to wait for hand-outs from bankrupt governments. In addition, experts advise that the peak of the virus spread should fall in June, precisely as winter hits South America. When you add to this the fact that developing countries have less old population and less “diseases of civilization” like diabetes or heart problems, this makes you wonder if the solution is worse than the disease.  </p>\n<p>Behold! My family in full lockdown in Buenos Aires (41 days and counting…)</p>\n<p>I wish I could say I’m one of those great moms who creates an activity for their kids to play and heal in such difficult time, but I’m not. I just can’t survive without a project.</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/04/irina-werning-la-cuarentena/attachment/1-la-cuarentena/'><img width=\"2240\" height=\"3360\" data-large-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/8-LA-CUARENTENA.jpg?fit=800%2C554&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<div>\n<h3>Bio</h3>\n</div>\n<div>\n<p>Irina grew up in Buenos Aires. She studied a BA in Economics and an MA in History. She began to travel in Asia and Middle East and ended up in London where she studied an MA in Photojournalism and lived for 7 years. She’s now back in Buenos Aires and focuses on personal long term projects. She loves to build sets and invent stages for her subjects. She can spend hours in a tool shop. </p>\n</div>\n<div> </div>\n<div>\n<h3>Related Links</h3>\n<p><a class=\"sc-jbKcbu ftkFFW\">Gianmarco Maraviglia</h4>\n</div>\n<h2>Winter Came in Spring</h2>\n<div>\n<div>\n<div class=\"page\" title=\"Page 3\">\n<div class=\"layoutArea\">\n<div class=\"column\">\n<p>We&#8217;ve seen the masks. We&#8217;ve seen hospitals and cemeteries. As always happens as reaction to a dramatic event there are different stages, different approaches. Then there is the everyday life. The search for a new normal, new rhythms, something to hold on to pretend that everything is fine.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div>\n\n<a data-orig-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/DSCF4299-1.jpg?fit=1920%2C1280&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"1920,1280\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;5&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;GIANMARCO MARAVIGLIA&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;X-T2&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1585053593&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;12&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;2500&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0.016666666666667&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"DSCF4299\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/DSCF4299-1.jpg?fit=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/DSCF4299-1.jpg?fit=800%2C534&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n</div>\n<div> </div>\n<div>Most of our life certainty is nothing more than repetitions. The alarm clock that rings at the same time, children go to school, cooking in the evening, going to bed knowing what is going to happen the next day. A kind of rhythm of existence. But when rhythm breaks down, it turns out how fragile is the balance we base our lives on. On the other side, leaving this safety zone forces you to find new dynamics, to search for new geometries from chaos.</div>\n<div>\n<div>As in an unexpected chemical reaction, the elements seek a new stability, a new order. Covid has already brought about enormous changes in our society, and the humans appear again capable of adapting with extreme speed, in search of a new balance. The same dynamics are found in a family, closed at home for two months, looking for a new form of everyday life.</div>\n</div>\n<div> </div>\n<div>\n\n<a src=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/DSCF4031-1.jpg?fit=1920%2C1280&#38;ssl=1\" class=\"attachment-full size-full\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/DSCF4031-1.jpg?w=1920&#38;ssl=1 1920w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/DSCF4031-1.jpg?resize=1024%2C683&#38;ssl=1 1024w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/DSCF4031-1.jpg?w=1600&#38;ssl=1 1600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" data-attachment-id=\"69567\" data-permalink=\"https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/04/gianmarco-maraviglia-winter-came-in-spring/attachment/dscf4031-2/\" data-orig-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/DSCF4031-1.jpg?fit=1920%2C1280&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"1920,1280\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;18&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;GIANMARCO MARAVIGLIA&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;X-T2&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1584815280&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;19.6&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;2500&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0.016666666666667&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"DSCF4031\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/DSCF4031-1.jpg?fit=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/DSCF4031-1.jpg?fit=800%2C534&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n</div>\n<div> </div>\n<div>Here in Milano, Lombardia, Italy &#8211; perhaps the most affected area in the world by the new coronavirus &#8211; this year here winter came in spring. Italy has been in a lock down situation for two months now. The emergency laws enacted by the government are among the most restrictive in the world. You cannot leave the house without a self-certification, and only for urgent reasons. As a photojournalist I worked on the news, on the empty streets, on the masks &#8230; But as a narrator I could do nothing but visually tell the changes that were happening quickly around me. </div>\n<div>\n<div>\n<h3>Bio</h3>\n</div>\n<div>\n<p>A humanistic background allows me to get closer to the stories I tell with the respect that every person deserves, respect for being told for what they really are, avoiding the path of visual spectacle of pain or poverty. I believe in the value of information as the first thing, for this reason my research does not stop only to the dramatic stories, because our world is fortunately still able to offer stories of great redemption, of rebirths, stories not yet told but that give hope for the future. I have the pleasure of working with magazines like Der Spiegel, Washington Post, CNN, Corriere Della Sera, Io Donna, Mare, Cicero and many others. I&#8217;m the proud founder of the <em>non-fiction communication and brand journalism collective</em> <a href=\"http://www.jollyjollygrog.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Jolly Jolly Grog</a>. I&#8217;m also a teacher of photojournalism at IED Milano and Officine Fotografiche. I hope to leave a better world to my two kids, Olivia and Yago.</p>\n</div>\n<div> </div>\n<div>\n<h3>Related Links</h3>\n<p><a 31-1.jpg?fit=1920%2C1280&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn59@2020_2/2020/08/25/01-16-26-307_41883d35137158a4.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598318178413},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/23-Detail-of-Internment-Camp-in-Kistarcsa-Hungary.-f6de19f9-a914-4306-a8d1-4de51475ebce_2.jpg?w=2400&#38;ssl=1 2400w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\" /></h4>\n<h4 class=\"sc-jbKcbu ftkFFW\">Daniel Kovalovszky</h4>\n</div>\n<h2>An Infernal Play</h2>\n<h5>[ EPF 2019 FINALIST ]</h5>\n<p>In 1945 Mátyás Rákosi, the leader of the Hungarian Communist Party, following the Soviet example, introduced a new Stalinist dictatorship in which human rights were severely violated.  As a result of show trials, several hundred thousands of political convicts were sent to forced labor camps, were imprisoned and hundreds were executed based on fictional charges. In most cases the charges consisted in supplying data to western powers and secretly organizing a revolt against the people’s power. Having found the memoirs of the political prisoner a very dreadful and unknown world opened up for me. I decided to start a visual collection to shed light on a segment of what was happening during these obscure years that is unknown to many but still significant: the world of prisons in Hungary between 1945 and 1963.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/1-forced-labor-camp-in-recsk-hungary-nothing-else-remains-for-you-who-enter-only-hope-f4082675-1161-4874-8653-bae6174ba0fc_1/'><img width=\"2362\" height=\"3000\" data-orig-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8-Portrait-of-Lajos-Kovács.-c66ebdb3-d48a-4659-bcd4-02a35727a658_2.jpg?fit=2363%2C3000&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"2363,3000\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;PerfectionV700&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;1&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"8 &#8211; Portrait of Lajos Kovács. &#8211; c66ebdb3-d48a-4659-bcd4-02a35727a658_2\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8-Portrait-of-Lajos-Kovács.-c66ebdb3-d48a-4659-bcd4-02a35727a658_2.jpg?fit=630%2C800&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8-Portrait-of-Lajos-Kovács.-c66ebdb3-d48a-4659-bcd4-02a35727a658_2.jpg?fit=800%2C1015&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>This world is disappearing unnoticed, and with the last old surviving witnesses and scenes. There is a time pressure for my work as there are fewer and fewer former prisoners who are still alive, and the places themselves also continuously disappear or change their function. The scenes will be holding the remembrance of the physical and mental suffering of thousands for a long time. This is the time to record what happened in the past for the next generations, because it will not be possible to do this in 3-4 years.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/9-internment-camp-in-kistarcsa-e7de50fb-04ac-4f42-91d3-e0364c578861_2/'><img width=\"2363\" height=\"3000\" data-orig-size=\"2362,3000\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;PerfectionV700&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;1&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"16 &#8211; Portrait of János Straub. &#8211; 40cf54ef-3187-408c-8498-eb9fa53dea29_2\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/16-Portrait-of-János-Straub.-40cf54ef-3187-408c-8498-eb9fa53dea29_2.jpg?fit=630%2C800&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/16-Portrait-of-János-Straub.-40cf54ef-3187-408c-8498-eb9fa53dea29_2.jpg?fit=800%2C1016&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>My work (2016-2019) is about the old survivors who spent long years in the &#8216;darkest&#8217; prisons and labor camps of the dictatorship I documented. They live privately, hidden from publicity, carrying this heavy historical burden for which they no time left in their lives to process and they still haven&#8217;t received proper moral or financial compensation for their sufferings. I made long interviews with the old political prisoners which have significantly changed my personal approach to the 20th century history of Hungary. I hope my work will also become historically meaningful at one point and can show something to the future generations.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/17-gallows-in-the-small-prison-eefd774b-7816-48e8-8d03-2c64f079e4ab_2/'><img width=\"2362\" height=\"3000\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h3>Short Bio</h3>\n<div class=\"sc-RefOD kyWBYY\">\n<div class=\"sc-cqpYsc iCVdLz\">\n<p class=\"sc-fQejPQ gxlmwq Paragraph-sc-972wlj-0 cOTQqy\">Daniel lives and works in Hungary. After graduating from high school, he studied portrait photography and photojournalism in Budapest and has been working as a photographer since 2001. Between 2001 and 2010, he made several documentary photography essays, mostly about aging in Hungary. Over the last few years, he has become deeply interested in landscape and portrait photography, working on long-term and conceptual projects. His works have been exhibited in several galleries and museums in Eastern Europe and the United Kingdom.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n<aside class=\"sc-iQKALj lowtCN\">\n<div class=\"sc-bwCtUz jmIOcX\" title=\"Daniel Kovalovszky\"> </div>\n</aside>\n<h3>Related Links</h3>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.kovalovszky.com\">www.kovalovszky.com</a></p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">&#8212;&#8211;</p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"> </p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">The Emerging Photographer Fund is supported by generous donors to the Magnum Foundation</p>\n<p><img data-attachment-id=\"58539\" data-permalink=\"https://www.burnmagazine.org/magnumfoundation/\" data-orig-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/magnumfoundation.png?fit=490%2C199&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"490,199\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\" /></h4>\n<h4>Mafalda Rakoš</h4>\n<h2>A Story to Tell</h2>\n<h5>[ FUJIFILM/YOUNG TALENT AWARD 2019 FINALIST ] </h5>\n<p>&#8220;You don’t really fit in… You don’t fit into the group of normal people, because you’re anorexic. And you don’t fit with those affected by anorexia, because you’re a man.“ &#8211; Thomas, 21. Our process always starts with a conversation. What does it look like, your mental cage? What do you feel, see, think, hear, taste and smell? And where shall we go to take that picture of it? <em>A Story to Tell</em> resulted from many encounters with ten men affected by anorexia, bulimia and binge eating. Being well-aqcuainted with the topic myself, I was wondering: how is it to be affected as a male? The protagonists of this project, many of them trans*, gay, bisexual or otherwise associated with a genderdiverse community want to show: everyone can be affected.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/03/mafalda-rakos-a-story-to-tell/attachment/2-leroy-2019-dbbb9e18-ac95-4ba0-9ad8-63e98b52499d/'><img width=\"1600\" height=\"1264\" 100vw, 800px\" data-attachment-id=\"69126\" data-permalink=\"https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/03/mafalda-rakos-a-story-to-tell/attachment/7-video-stills_-_loss-fears-526637d5-8b7a-4f0e-bc42-9281bbde7dc2/\" data-orig-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/7-Video-Stills_-_Loss-fears“-526637d5-8b7a-4f0e-bc42-9281bbde7dc2.jpg?fit=1600%2C969&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"1600,969\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"7 &#8211; Video Stills_ _Loss fears“ &#8211; 526637d5-8b7a-4f0e-bc42-9281bbde7dc2\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/7-Video-Stills_-_Loss-fears“-526637d5-8b7a-4f0e-bc42-9281bbde7dc2.jpg?fit=800%2C485&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/7-Video-Stills_-_Loss-fears“-526637d5-8b7a-4f0e-bc42-9281bbde7dc2.jpg?fit=800%2C484&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>Very often, it was shocking to listen. They told us about the shame, invisibility and unrecognition that they experience, not rarely resulting in serious self–harm and even suicide attempts. Their stories were more extreme, more violent and more painful than I would normally hear it from women. Yet, together with journalist Ruben de Theije, we kept drilling towards the true conflicts in the intersection of social expectations and big emotions; conflicts that lie at the heart of the stories they wanted to tell.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/03/mafalda-rakos-a-story-to-tell/attachment/8-leroy-2018-b814f691-c4fe-42f3-a555-5d8bbba6afa9/'><img data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"18 &#8211; Markus, 2018 &#8211; 42d257d9-4e7e-463a-8a71-b975333f8b7d\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/18-Markus-2018-42d257d9-4e7e-463a-8a71-b975333f8b7d.jpg?fit=800%2C644&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/18-Markus-2018-42d257d9-4e7e-463a-8a71-b975333f8b7d.jpg?fit=800%2C644&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h3>Short Bio</h3>\n<p>Mafalda Rakoš (*1994, AT) is a visual artist based between Austria and the Netherlands. Educated at the Royal Academy of Art (KABK) in The Hague and Academy of Fina Arts in Vienna, she also holds a BA in Anthropology from Vienna University. Her projects often move along the intersection of art, documentary and journalism and attempt to dive deep into protagonist’s stories around safety, pain and trauma. Since 2013, she has been researching eating disorders through a collaborative and research-based practise rooted in documentary photography and cultural anthropology. The main platform of her work are books which gained attention in contests such as Kassel Dummy Award and the European Publishers Award for Photography; furthermore, it is regularly shown in international exhibitions and other contexts such as congresses for eating disorders (2016), or a hospital (2017). It was recognized by Awards such as c/o Berlin New Documentary Talent, the Steenbergen Stipendium and the Documentary Project Fund Emerging Vision Award.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h3>Related Links</h3>\n<p><a href=\"http://www.mafaldarakos.com\">mafaldarakos.com</a></p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">&#8212;&#8211;</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">The /></h3>\n<h3><strong>Giorgio Bianchi</strong></h3>\n</div>\n<h2>Donbass Stories</h2>\n<p>Several tens of thousands of dead and wounded, over a million refugees. The civil war in Donbass has literally erased entire cities and villages from the map, staining with blood the soil of the European continent for the first time in the twenty-first century.</p>\n<p>These are two chapters &#8211; Alina and Blind Pit &#8211; of my Donbass Stories,  which came to life with the idea to portray as main characters those invisible actors affected by the civil war in that region.</p>\n<h2><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\">Alina</span></h2>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/05/giorgio-bianchi-donbass-stories/attachment/donbass-stories-alina_01/'><img width=\"2097\" height=\"1400\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;2.8&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;Giorgio Bianchi&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;NIKON data-image-title=\"Donbass stories &#8211; Alina_43\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Donbass-stories-Alina_43.jpg?fit=800%2C534&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Donbass-stories-Alina_43.jpg?fit=800%2C534&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/05/giorgio-bianchi-donbass-stories/attachment/donbass-stories-alina_46/'><img width=\"2100\" height=\"1400\" src=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Donbass-stories-Alina_46.jpg?fit=2100%2C1400&#38;ssl=1\" class=\"attachment-full size-full\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Donbass-stories-Alina_46.jpg?w=2100&#38;ssl=1 2100w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Donbass-stories-Alina_46.jpg?resize=170%2C113&#38;ssl=1 170w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Donbass-stories-Alina_46.jpg?resize=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1 800w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Donbass-stories-Alina_46.jpg?resize=768%2C512&#38;ssl=1 768w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Donbass-stories-Alina_46.jpg?resize=1024%2C683&#38;ssl=1 1024w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Donbass-stories-Alina_46.jpg?w=1600&#38;ssl=1 1600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" data-attachment-id=\"70026\" data-permalink=\"https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/05/giorgio-bianchi-donbass-stories/attachment/donbass-stories-alina_46/\" data-orig-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Donbass-stories-Alina_46.jpg?fit=2100%2C1400&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"2100,1400\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;2.8&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;X-T2&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1490537227&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;18&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;1600&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0.004&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;1&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"Donbass stories &#8211; Alina_46\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Donbass-stories-Alina_46.jpg?fit=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Donbass-stories-Alina_46.jpg?fit=800%2C534&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>Despite power cuts, a shutdown of all businesses, curfews, and nearly daily shelling, residents of the rebel-held city of Donetsk flock to the Opera and Ballet Theater on weekends in search of respite from the reality of life within a battle zone. When war broke out around a third of the theater&#8217;s performers fled, including key singers and all four of its conductors. A further setback occurred when a wayward missile destroyed the warehouse where most of the stage sets were stored.</p>\n<p>The opera house was forced to close in July 2015 because of heavy clashes, then it recruited new staff and was again operative the following September. Despite the ongoing hostilities and challenging circumstances, audience figures at the 960-seat theater have been impressive since its reopening. In the ground floor cloakroom, camouflage military jackets hang among civilian furs and overcoats.</p>\n<p>Alina is a professional dancer from Donetsk and a member of the Donbass Opera and Ballet Theatre chorus. She has been studying at the theatre academy since she was a girl and throughout the entire war period she has continued to dance, convinced that keeping performances alive was one of the few ways to make sure the inhabitants of her city would not think about the horrors of war, if only for a few hours.</p>\n<p>The rhythm of Alina&#8217;s life follows the timings of the theater: from Tuesday to Friday she has ballet lessons and rehearsals, on Saturday and Sunday the performances; Monday is the only day off the performers have and she goes to visit her maternal grandparents with whom she is very close, or she meets up with her ballet girlfriends to take a walk around town or go to the disco. Even if she doesn’t intend to leave her hometown at the moment, she doesn’t rule out the possibility of moving to Russia in case of an escalation of the war.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h2><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\">Blind Pit: The Story of Sasha</span></h2>\n<div class=\"uncoltable\">\n<div class=\"uncell no-block-padding\">\n<div class=\"uncont\">\n<div class=\"uncode_text_column\"><a href=\"http://produzionidalbasso.com/project/blind-pit/.\">Sasha</a> is a sightless 31-year-old miner. He works in one of the many independent (kopanki) mines located around the small town of Torez. Raised with three brothers in a dysfunctional family, Sasha lost his sight when he was 11, because of a very bad accident. </div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"uncont\">\n<div> </div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/05/giorgio-bianchi-donbass-stories/attachment/donbass-stories-sasha_26/'><img https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Donbass-stories-Sasha_20.jpg?resize=768%2C513&#38;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Donbass-stories-Sasha_20.jpg?resize=1024%2C684&#38;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Donbass-stories-Sasha_20.jpg?w=1600&#38;ssl=1 1600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" data-attachment-id=\"69940\" data-permalink=\"https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/05/giorgio-bianchi-donbass-stories/attachment/donbass-stories-sasha_20/\" data-orig-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Donbass-stories-Sasha_20.jpg?fit=2097%2C1400&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"2097,1400\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;4.5&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;Giorgio Bianchi&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;NIKON D750&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1490629869&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;Giorgio Bianchi&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;27&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;1100&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0.008&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;1&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"Donbass stories &#8211; Sasha_20\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Donbass-stories-Sasha_20.jpg?fit=800%2C534&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Donbass-stories-Sasha_20.jpg?fit=800%2C534&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<div class=\"uncoltable\">\n<div class=\"uncell no-block-padding\">\n<div class=\"uncont\">\n<div class=\"uncode_text_column\">\n<div class=\"uncode_text_column\"> </div>\n<div>After a long cohabitation, he married Evgenija (Genia), who had two children – Valerija (15) and Alexander (11) – from a previous marriage. One year ago their third child, Anja, was born. Due to the conflict, the zootechnical farm where they both worked closed down, leaving all the workers without jobs. Because of the economic crisis resulting from the war, many people from the area were forced to choose between joining the separatist militias and trying to get hired at one of the dozens independent coal mines surrounding the city of Torez.</div>\n<div>Nonetheless, Sasha remained unemployed for a long time, because nobody would trust hiring a blind man – least of all mine managers – even if his determination and high productivity were widely known. Then, one day he met a Tartar called Ildar, owner of a kopanko, who offered him a job. Since then, Sasha has gone to the mine every day, at 6:30 a.m., led by his father, a miner as well, and goes back home eight hours later with his wife, or one of his elder children. From his house to the mine it’s a 30-minute walk, through fields and woods.</div>\n<div>The mine where Sasha works is a thick net of underground tunnels that are never higher than 4 feet and in some places are less than 1.6 feet. These tunnels run under a small natural pond and go as deep as 300 yards. This means that in many places the mine is flooded, which makes it even harder for Sasha and his colleagues to reach the mineral vein. Sasha can go down the mineshaft as quickly and as nimbly as his colleagues. Despite his disability, he has learned to navigate confidently the underground maze, to avoid obstacles and to dodge dangers posed by the uneven beams of the roof, the puddles of water, the slippery clay and the extraction devices placed along the path. His mental map of the mine is made of a continuous flow of sensations that take him, one orderly step after another, to the mine’s core. Sasha’s task is to pour with a shovel the coal, that’s been broken to pieces with a jackhammer, into steel tanks that will bring it to the surface. Sqeezed in a cavity less than 15 feet high, surrounded by the deafening noise of pneumatic drills, covered with coal powder, and immersed in total darkness, made even deeper by his blindness. Accidents are extremely frequent, as it’s well known despite the fact that there are no available official statistics; in the same fashion, there is no available documentation regarding the disease and mortality incidence – well above national average  – among miners due to poor working conditions. Nonetheless, kopankas remain the only source of income for thousands of families.</div>\n<div>According to specialists who have visited him through the years, Sasha’s blindness is reversible and could be cured with a corneal transplant. Recently, Sasha has decided to go for the surgery that could help him regain his sight. He and his wife went to the Fyodorov clinics, in Krasnodar and then in Moscow, to undergo preoperative testing. Unfortunately, his healing process is slow and full of uncertainties because of the high cost of the treatment. Maybe one day, upon exiting the mine, Sasha will be able to smile along with his collegues, on seeing the sunlight again, after eight hours spent in darkness.</div>\n<div><i>With director Federico Schiavi, Bianchi is working to create a <a href=\"https://vimeo.com/402973996\">documentary</a> from Sasha&#8217;s story. In order to maintain maximum independence and freedom of movement, they are running a <a href=\"http://produzionidalbasso.com/project/blind-pit/.\">crowdfunding campaign</a> to raise the necessary funds to develop this work. </i></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<div>\n<h3>Bio</h3>\n</div>\n<div>\n<p>Giorgio Bianchi is an Italian photojournalist, documentarist, writer and filmmaker (Rome in 1973).<span class=\"Apple-converted-space\"> </span>In his work Giorgio has always paid particular attention to political and anthropological issues, and has undertaken a freelance career to focus on a combination of long-term personal projects and client assignments.<span class=\"Apple-converted-space\">  </span>He has covered stories in Syria, Ukraine, Burkina Faso, Vietnam, Myanmar, Nepal, India, and throughout all of Europe. <span class=\"Apple-converted-space\"> </span></p>\n<p>Since 2013, he has made several trips to Ukraine, where he followed closely the Ukrainian crisis from the Euromaidan protests until the outbreak of war between the government army and the pro-Russian separatists.<span class=\"Apple-converted-space\">  </span>Thanks to his robust archive of footage and pictures about the Donbass conflict he is making a documentary film entitled “Apocalypse Donbass”. In 2016 he started covering the Syrian conflict.<span class=\"Apple-converted-space\"> </span></p>\n<p>Giorgio has won several international prizes and has received many public recognitions, and his pictures are regularly published in newspapers and magazines, both paper and online.<span class=\"Apple-converted-space\">  </span>His work has been exhibited in many international and national festivals.<span class=\"Apple-converted-space\"> </span></p>\n</div>\n<div> </div>\n<div>\n<h3>Related Links</h3>\n</div>\n<div>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.giorgiobianchiphotojournalist.com\">giorgiobianchiphotojournalist.com</a></p>\n<p><a href=\"http://produzionidalbasso.com/project/blind-pit/.\">crowdfunding campaign </a></p>\n<p><a href=\"https://vimeo.com/402973996\">film trailer</a> </p>\n</div>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 29 May 2020 10:02:11 data-recalc-dims=\"1\" /></h4>\n<h4>Ingmar Björn Nolting</h4>\n<h2>Somaliland</h2>\n<h5>[ FUJIFILM/YOUNG TALENT AWARD 2019 FINALIST ] </h5>\n<p>The Horn of Africa is regarded as one of the continent&#8217;s most war-torn regions. Somalia in particular crashed into an ever deeper chaos of civil war and terror after the disempowerment of the Somali dictator Siad Barre in 1991. There is still no end in sight. Despite all resistance, however, an island of peaceful coexistence emerged in the north of the country. Somaliland. The borders of Somaliland go back to the area of the former British protectorate, which united with Italian-Somaliland to Somalia in 1960. Under the dictatorship of Barre, who seized power through a putsch in 1969, the inhabitants of the north felt increasingly deprived. The resulting fights of the guerilla group &#8220;Somaliland National Movement&#8221; against the Barre regime culminated in the overthrow of the Barre regime, the adoption of a declaration of independence and the founding of the Republic of Somaliland on 18 May 1991.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/1-somaliland_nolting_01-77baaf26-b49a-494e-8096-cec5c1b8b857/'><img width=\"5000\" height=\"4000\" data-attachment-id=\"67801\" data-permalink=\"https://www.burnmagazine.org/1-somaliland_nolting_01-77baaf26-b49a-494e-8096-cec5c1b8b857/\" data-orig-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1-Somaliland_Nolting_01-77baaf26-b49a-494e-8096-cec5c1b8b857.jpg?fit=5000%2C4000&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"5000,4000\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;2&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;X-Pro2&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;Zuhaib (16) and Zakiriye (16) pose on the training grounds of the New Somaliland Circus in Hargeisa, Somaliland. Since there is no circus culture in Somaliland, the shows of the young artists attract a lot of attention, especially in rural areas. The circus group performs in all regions of the country and uses the audience&#039;s attention to educate about HIV, malaria, female genital mutilation and the risks of migration to Europe. Every year, young men die on the way, in the Mediterranean or are kidnapped in Libya. The circus thus becomes a tool of education and gives the young artists self-esteem and a mission.&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1556469879&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;23&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;1250&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0.008&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" data-orig-size=\"3200,4000\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;2&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;X-Pro2&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;Ahmed (29) poses in the living room of his house in Hargeisa, Somaliland. He grew up in America and decided to return to the country of his parents two years ago in order to learn Somali and contribute to the development of the country. He met his wife in Hargeisa, married her and they had a child. Today he can no longer imagine moving back to America. Ahmed volunteers as a teacher in the \\&#34;Family, career and community leaders of Somaliland\\&#34; (FCCLS) project. FCCLS has made it its mission to educate young men and women beyond regular, often inadequate schooling to become responsible leaders who will later change and develop the country.&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1558115943&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;23&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;6400&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0.008&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" data-attachment-id=\"67804\" data-permalink=\"https://www.burnmagazine.org/4-somaliland_nolting_04-35962c48-ae3b-4a10-b8fd-158372d534b9/\" data-orig-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/4-Somaliland_Nolting_04-35962c48-ae3b-4a10-b8fd-158372d534b9.jpg?fit=5000%2C4000&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"5000,4000\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;3.6&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;X-Pro2&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;Nomads at an oasis near Biyo-Guure southeast of the port city of Berbera. Muna (11) and Mohamed (12), left in the picture, lead the 50 goats of their family every day to this small creed. In the aridity of the last years the creek dried up, 50 of their goats died. Approximately half of the inhabitants of Somaliland live as nomads outside the towns and villages, the livestock is their most important living basis. The continuing droughts of recent years have killed about 70 percent of Somaliland&#039;s livestock and forced tens of thousands of families to flee to the cities&#039; IDP camps. Climate change has led to temperature changes in the Indian Ocean, pushing the wind and humid air that usually brings rain away from the mainland. The effects of climate change are increasingly affecting the entire Horn of Africa, leading to water scarcity, starvation and flight.&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1557217643&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;23&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;200&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0.00058823529411765&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" Somaliland for the day. The currency of Somaliland, the Somaliland Shilling, is not internationally recognized and cannot be changed or traded outside the country. During the noon prayer the moneychangers leave their stand to pray in a nearby mosque, leaving the money unattended. Due to the social control by the clan system, the country is largely safe. Thieves are usually quickly identified and arrested by the police, who have a strong presence in the The IDP camps around Hargeisa are mainly supplied by international NGOs, but there are often shortages, too little access to water and data-orig-size=\"5000,4000\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;2.8&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;X-Pro2&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;Ahmed (29) prays at the Dahabshiil Mosque in Hargeisa, Somaliland. Islam is the main religion of the country and determines the daily life of the population. After the end of the guerrilla war against the troops of the Somali dictator Siad Barre and the subsequent declaration of independence of Somaliland, large parts of the population filled the accrued political and social vacuum with religion and found hope in data-orig-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8-Somaliland_Nolting_08-1542d43a-7e02-4ec5-ae8f-ac650cad5775.jpg?fit=3200%2C4000&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"3200,4000\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;2&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;X-Pro2&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;Mohamed Arab Geele (52) posing for a portrait in the Veteran Association in Hargeisa, Somaliland. At the age of 18 he joined the guerilla group \\&#34;Somaliland National Movement\\&#34; (SNM) and fought against the troops of Siad Barre. The inhabitants of the north felt strongly disadvantaged under his dictatorship, in the north there was too little water, little food and no university. More and more inhabitants of the villages occupied by the SNM joined the SNM. In 1988, after a three-month fight for Hargeisa, Mohamed was injured by a bomb splinter in his knee. Barre&#039;s troops bombed Hargeisa with fighter jets starting from the airport on the outskirts of Hargeisa. Since the clan elders proclaimed Somaliland&#039;s independence in 1991, Mohamed has been hoping for international recognition.&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1556432618&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;23&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;2000&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0.008&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" data-attachment-id=\"67815\" data-permalink=\"https://www.burnmagazine.org/10-somaliland_nolting_10-205395bf-80fd-48e2-a623-31962c16aad9/\" data-orig-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/10-Somaliland_Nolting_10-205395bf-80fd-48e2-a623-31962c16aad9.jpg?fit=5000%2C4000&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"5000,4000\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;2&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;X-Pro2&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;Abdizamad (19) poses together with his mother Qali Rooble (50) in their room in Hargeisa, Somaliland. Abdizamad began his journey to Europe in July 2017 without telling his mother. He paid smugglers who gave him instructions by telephone, guided him through Ethiopia to Sudan and from there to Libya. In Libya, he was kidnapped, beaten and held in a house with other refugees. The traffickers demanded a ransom of 5500 dollars from his family. 15 of his family members joined forces and bought him free after five months. Abdizamad got on a boat that was supposed to take him across the Mediterranean to Europe after all. After two days at sea, the refugees were taken on board of an NGO ship and brought back to Libya. There he was detained for three months and then returned to Hargeisa. His family raised 2,000 dollars and he opened a small shop. Many of the young people in Somaliland do not see any perspective in their homeland. Unemployment, poverty and the hope for a better life drive them into the arms of the traffickers on their way to Europe.&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1556192835&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;23&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;1000&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0.008&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;1&#34;}\" data-orig-size=\"5000,4000\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;3.6&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;X-Pro2&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;During Ramadan, young men sit on the banks of the Gulf of Aden in Berbera, Somaliland, waiting for breaking the fast at sunset. Somaliland&#039;s largest source of income comes from the port of Berbera. Somaliland mainly exports livestock to the Arab Gulf states.&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1557159663&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;23&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;200&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0.004&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"11 &#8211; Somaliland_Nolting_11 &#8211; 47016166-5282-427e-991a-b30e88898596\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11-Somaliland_Nolting_11-47016166-5282-427e-991a-b30e88898596.jpg?fit=800%2C640&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11-Somaliland_Nolting_11-47016166-5282-427e-991a-b30e88898596.jpg?fit=800%2C640&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>During my work in Somaliland, I have focused on issues of migration, climate change and aspects of democracy and state-building to create a portrait of the often overlooked region, which has been seeking international recognition for 28 years and where nothing seems more important than the young peace. The project is ongoing.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/13-somaliland_nolting_13-01799384-9640-4e32-b1a5-4e94d6a37f41/'><img width=\"3200\" height=\"4000\" data-orig-size=\"3200,4000\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;Asiya kayd Zandan (56) poses on the grounds of the IDP camp of \\&#34;Norwegian Refugee Council\\&#34; in Burao, Somaliland. Asiya belongs to the minority group \\&#34;Gabooye\\&#34;, which is a kind of work caste. People who are attributed to the minority often work in manual, lower professions and are affected by discrimination. Asiya is divorced from her husband, who now lives in Mogadishu and does not support her.&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1559135066&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" data-orig-size=\"5000,4000\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;2&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;X-Pro2&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;Hassan (23), Abdiadiqadir (20) and Mohamed (19) pose on the campus of the Faculty of Agriculture and Environment of Amoud University in Boorama, Somaliland. The university was the first in the country and opened in 1998. Before independence, there was no university in northern Somalia. The university writes about its faculty in brochures: \\u201eAt the moment, Agriculture in our country is subsistence agriculture (the production of enough food to meet just the needs of the farmer\\/agriculturalist and his\\/her family). Amoud university with the establishment of the faculty of agriculture wants to transform the current agricultural system into that of industrial agriculture, (often referred to as factory farming) long prevalent in \\&#34;developed\\&#34; nations and increasingly so elsewhere, which consists of obtaining financial income from the cultivation of land to yield produce, the commercial raising of animals (animal husbandry), or both.\\u201c&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1556791311&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;23&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;200&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0.0003125&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;1&#34;}\"
