data-orig-size=\"5000,4000\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;A young man crosses the dried-up riverbed that divides the Somali capital Hargeisa into North and South.&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1559136921&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;1&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"19 &#8211; Somaliland_Nolting_19 &#8211; 6b5e7c8a-2205-48a0-b999-e959f1854c8c\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/19-Somaliland_Nolting_19-6b5e7c8a-2205-48a0-b999-e959f1854c8c.jpg?fit=800%2C640&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/19-Somaliland_Nolting_19-6b5e7c8a-2205-48a0-b999-e959f1854c8c.jpg?fit=800%2C640&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h3>Short Bio</h3>\n<p>Ingmar Björn Nolting (1995) lives and works as a freelance documentary photographer in Leipzig, Germany. After finishing his A-levels, he volunteered to help the homeless and blind. Since then, Ingmar&#8217;s photographic work has focused on social documentary issues, in which he sets his sights on people and their habitats, which have disappeared from the public eye. With a slo­wer approach to his work process, he tries to understand how his protagonists think, feel and interact with each other, to absorb and understand what makes their lives. Ingmar is a founding member of „DOCKS Collective“ for humanistic photography. &#8211; Shortlist, Athens Photo Festival 2019 &#8211; Honorable Mention, New Generation Priza at Phmuseum Grant 2019 &#8211; Honorable Mention, PDNedu 2019, Portraiture &#8211; Winner, Emerge Visual Journalism Grant 2018 &#8211; Finalist, Vonovia Award of Photography 2018, Newcomer Award &#8211; Finalist of the LuganoPhotoDays Emerging Award, 2018 &#8211; Selected for Canon Masterclass, Visa pour l&#8217;image, Perpignan 2018 &#8211; Winner of Vonovia Award of Photography 2017, Newcomer Award &#8211; Shortlisted for Felix Schoeller Photo Award 2017, Best Emerging Photographer &#8211; Finalist for Kolga Award 2017, Newcomer Award &#8211; Nominated for Kolga Award 2017, Best Documentary &#8211; Awardee, German Youth Photography Award 2016 &#8211; Scholarship, granted by the German Ministry for Education and Research &#8211; Participant NikonNOOR Workshop, C/O Berlin</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h3>Related Links</h3>\n<p><a href=\"https://ingmarnolting.de\">www.ingmarnolting.de</a></p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p style=\"text-align: 0.jpg?fit=5000%2C4000&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn75@2020_1/2020/08/25/01-16-23-011_53cd810cbedd2fe9.webp","https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/17-Somaliland_Nolting_17-8d47be39-1732-41e6-a693-6ef4eb11326e.jpg?fit=5000%2C4000&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn8@2020_3/2020/08/25/01-16-27-466_3fce19ede9a3e706.webp","https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/18-Somaliland_Nolting_18-5b5bbb10-206b-4b17-8672-22649bdb7e4f.jpg?fit=3200%2C4000&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn91@2020_4/2020/08/25/01-16-27-726_e511d9c6eb312a18.webp","https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/19-Somaliland_Nolting_19-6b5e7c8a-2205-48a0-b999-e959f1854c8c.jpg?fit=5000%2C4000&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn55@2020_3/2020/08/25/01-16-23-059_db9e2f98e975a129.webp","https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/FujiFilm_Basic-Black-1.png?resize=100%2C86":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn44@2020_3/2020/08/25/01-16-24-066_1830dfe08ed7f9c8.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598318178427},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 data-recalc-dims=\"1\" /></a></h4>\n<h4>Chris Donovan</h4>\n<h2>The Cloud Factory</h2>\n<h5>[ FUJIFILM/YOUNG TALENT AWARD 2019 FINALIST ] </h5>\n<p>As a child, I looked up at the billowing smoke stacks of the refinery and asked my father if they made all of the world’s clouds. “No,” he replied. “They make money.” I grew up in Saint John, New Brunswick &#8211; an industrial city on the east coast of Canada &#8211; bookended by Canada’s largest oil refinery and a pulp mill owned by the same billionaire family. Despite the enormous wealth controlled by the Irving family, we also have the highest rate of child poverty in Canada, at around 50%. This billionaire family also owns every newspaper in the province. The Cloud Factory project is my way of fighting against censorship and addressing the environmental and social implications of industrial classism on my community.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/02/chris-donovan-the-cloud-factory/attachment/2-untitled-522e17ea-3418-40d4-a9f6-442a0b855141-3/'><img width=\"2101\" height=\"1680\" href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/02/chris-donovan-the-cloud-factory/attachment/13-untitled-cdde42e1-2265-4113-8e51-c82d75a8adb7-2/'><img width=\"2100\" height=\"1680\" https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/13-Untitled-cdde42e1-2265-4113-8e51-c82d75a8adb7.jpg?w=1600&#38;ssl=1 1600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" data-attachment-id=\"68820\" data-permalink=\"https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/02/chris-donovan-the-cloud-factory/attachment/13-untitled-cdde42e1-2265-4113-8e51-c82d75a8adb7-2/\" data-orig-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/13-Untitled-cdde42e1-2265-4113-8e51-c82d75a8adb7.jpg?fit=2100%2C1680&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"2100,1680\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"13 &#8211; Untitled &#8211; cdde42e1-2265-4113-8e51-c82d75a8adb7\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/13-Untitled-cdde42e1-2265-4113-8e51-c82d75a8adb7.jpg?fit=800%2C640&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/13-Untitled-cdde42e1-2265-4113-8e51-c82d75a8adb7.jpg?fit=800%2C640&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>Jacques Poitras, author of Irving vs Irving, says of the Irving control of the media: “Newspapers are a historical record of our time. The concern with the Irving papers is not what is being written about, but what is being left out.” The goal of project is to fill in some of these blanks. For residents of the Bayside neighborhood, adjacent to the refinery, it feels like a lot is being left out. Resident Lisa Jacquart says her non-smoking neighbors are “dropping like flies” of lung cancer. With no studies on the air quality in this specific neighborhood, it&#8217;s impossible to hold the company accountable for these issues. Canada is now at a crossroads. A proposal to create the country’s longest-ever pipeline, which would transport oil to the refinery in Saint John, is currently on hold. As we get closer to electing a conservative Prime Minister in the Fall, that is expected to change. This is a complicated story of a town that relies on a damaging industry for survival. It must be approached with nuance and collaboration. As a Saint Johner, this is my story, and I hope you can help me tell it. Thank you for your consideration.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/02/chris-donovan-the-cloud-factory/attachment/14-untitled-886b68d1-f142-4bc0-aa17-b9353380b06c-2/'><img width=\"2100\" height=\"1680\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h3>Short Bio</h3>\n<p>Chris Donovan (b. 1995) is a visual storyteller based in Toronto, Canada. Hailing from a small industrial city on Canada’s east coast, most of his work focuses on the interplay between industry and community. Chris’ work has been recognized by POYi, the Sony World Photo Awards, and the Canadian Pictures of the Year &#8211; including being named Photojournalist of the Year in 2017 and 2018. Hi clients include The New York Times, The Washington Post, The Globe and Mail, Maclean’s Magazine, Reuters and others.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h3>Related Links</h3>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.chrisdonovan.ca/#1\">chrisdonovan.ca</a></p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">&#8212;&#8211;</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">The Fujifilm/Young data-image-title=\"DSCF1181\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/DSCF1181.jpeg?fit=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/DSCF1181.jpeg?fit=800%2C534&#38;ssl=1\" class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-69797\" src=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/DSCF1181.jpeg?resize=800%2C533&#038;ssl=1\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"533\" srcset=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/DSCF1181.jpeg?w=2100&#38;ssl=1 2100w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/DSCF1181.jpeg?resize=170%2C113&#38;ssl=1 170w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/DSCF1181.jpeg?resize=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1 800w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/DSCF1181.jpeg?resize=768%2C512&#38;ssl=1 768w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/DSCF1181.jpeg?resize=1024%2C683&#38;ssl=1 1024w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/DSCF1181.jpeg?w=1600&#38;ssl=1 1600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\" /></h4>\n<h4 class=\"sc-jbKcbu ftkFFW\">Daniel Hinks</h4>\n</div>\n<h2>In Sickness and in Health</h2>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">2020 this foul year of our lord. Disease, death and decay now plague the world. Rising nationalism, right-wing popularism, global economic fallout and political dogma are not the only virus to scourge this earth. The pandemic has spread globally, causing mass hysteria between the World Health Organization (WHO) and nations, causing mistrust and resentment. World leaders point fingers throw accusations playing the blame game like giddy little school children, seeming to forget that there is more at stake than a false ego and the pride of a nation.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Lest we forget it is human lives that are being played with, we are living in desperate times. Have we lost our humanity, our compassion, our humility for our fellow beings? After all, it was Confucius that said: &#8220;Under the sky&#8217;s and heavens we are all but one family&#8221;.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">China had put a blanket ban on gathering and large ceremonies such as weddings and funerals, during the first months of the pandemic to prevent further spread of the disease. As of March 25th, parts of China eased up on these restrictions. Each province and city govern themselves under a local municipal government, which is tightly monitored and complies with the laws and regulations of the central government. This makes things more manageable for smaller provinces and cities to resume business as usual under the proper measures in comparison to its counterparts across the country like Beijing, Shanghai, Guandong and Sichuan. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Shandong was one of these provinces that eased up on its restrictions rather quickly, due to its low level of recorded cases of Covid-19. Shandong is 746km away from the outbreak with a documented 788 confirmed cases and only 7 deaths. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Luckily enough for two traffic officers from ZaoZhuang in Shandong province, a population of 4.18Million people and only 24 reported cases and no deaths. Sun Meng, 27, and his bride to be Xu FeiFei, 31, were worried that their big day might not go ahead as planned. However, as luck has it, the ceremony was able to take place.</span></p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/DSCF1302.jpeg?resize=768%2C512&#38;ssl=1 768w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/DSCF1302.jpeg?resize=1024%2C683&#38;ssl=1 1024w, https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/DSCF1302.jpeg?w=1600&#38;ssl=1 1600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" data-attachment-id=\"69798\" data-permalink=\"https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/05/daniel-hinks-in-sickness-and-in-health/attachment/dscf1302-2/\" data-orig-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/DSCF1302.jpeg?fit=2100%2C1400&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"2100,1400\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;2&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;X-T2&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1587334527&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;23&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;640&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0.033333333333333&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;0&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"DSCF1302\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/DSCF1302.jpeg?fit=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/DSCF1302.jpeg?fit=800%2C534&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">There is an ancient Chinese tradition of selecting a date for the wedding. The use of both persons birth year that corresponds with the animal of that year is used. Along with the time of birth as they align with aspects of Wu Xing the five elements, this brings luck, prosperity and happiness to life and in marriage. It is believed that if you alter the date, it will bring challenges to your life along with pain, sorrow and anguish. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Sun Meng and Xu Fei Fei, despite their apprehensions, were over the moon to be able to spend their magic moment with their honored guests.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Putting politics and this cold-blooded bummer, which we find ourselves aside and taking a moment to appreciate this beautiful moment between two human beings, for what is a marriage. Love, compassion, tolerance and unity. Everything that makes us human. This wedding serves as a beacon of hope of the future. Shining its light through the darkness at the end of the tunnel.</span></p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<div>\n<h3>Bio</h3>\n</div>\n<div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">I am a documentary photographer, visual artist and trouble maker; I am constantly fascinated by the human condition. I take on stories that I truly believe in something that can peak my interest and curiosity, turning that energy outwards into creating work. Looking at the state of the human existence</span> <span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">but concentrating on the resilience of the human spirit.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">I have a profound belief that the still image has the ability to change people’s minds. Even in today’s modern forever changing fast paced world of now! now! now! and limited concentration spans. The access that your subjects allow me when working is imperative to the work that I create. I treat my subjects with complete respect and photograph them with dignity and complete diligence in order to help tell the truth and bring their stories to life.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">My work is intended to bring about understanding of different cultures, races, religions and bridge the gap between humans rather than extending it. Bringing people closer to create a more thoughtfully educated world.</span></p>\n</div>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<div>\n<h3>Related Links</h3>\n<p><a https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/1-We-are-the-ones-turning-I-39fda60e-30b3-4d16-80da-8f7cf80f6b11.jpg?w=2400&#38;ssl=1 2400w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\" /></h4>\n<h4>Ana Zibelnik</h4>\n<h2>We are the ones turning</h2>\n<h5>[ FUJIFILM/YOUNG TALENT AWARD 2019 FINALIST ] </h5>\n<p>The series is a reflection on something we all grapple with: dying. To make sense of what is constantly there – somewhere, sometimes latent, sometimes not so much – to better understand and bear the &#8220;possibility of impossibility&#8221; we tend to listen to those more experienced, similarly or more troubled than us. We read books and watch films and lend an ear to the occasional wise man speaking. My own idea of how we encounter the constant presence of death is greatly indebted to some of those who examined the infinitely compelling and defining nature of mortality in detail and put it down in ink. One of those who mark the conceptual backbone of my series is Martin Heidegger, who accurately noted that the paramount difference between man and everything else that lives, lies not in the ratio, but in mortality: “mortals are those who experience death as death&#8221;. In this sense, human beings are identified by the great absence. Not necessarily by fear of it or permanent anticipation, but by mere awareness of the fact – an awareness we are born with and is reinforced and revisited simply by living. My series is an exploration into the subtle encounters with death during lifetime. I wish to construe a vast and and intense fictional narrative that zooms in on what it means to be running out of time.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2019/12/ana-zibelnik-we-are-the-ones-turning/attachment/2-can-it-still-be-7b36193c-a430-4491-8664-d75f6396fa7e/'><img width=\"3000\" height=\"2571\" data-medium-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/19-A-map-does-not-know-where-you-stand-590d348f-93aa-4ec6-9e3b-d983affed388.jpg?fit=800%2C686&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/19-A-map-does-not-know-where-you-stand-590d348f-93aa-4ec6-9e3b-d983affed388.jpg?fit=800%2C686&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h3>Short Bio</h3>\n<p>Ana Zibelnik (b. 1995) is a photographer currently living and working in Leiden, Netherlands. After graduating summa cum laude from the Academy of Fine Arts and Design in Ljubljana with the thesis “Moment and Duration,” she decided to further pursue her studies in film and photographic theory at Leiden University. During the period between 2015 and 2018 she was part of the If Slovenia Were project, an intense mentorship programme led by a renowned French-Slovenian photographer Klavdij Sluban. In May 2018, she was selected as an emerging artist to participate in the second cycle of PARALLEL &#8211; European Photo Based Platform (founded by Procur.arte). The project she created in the scope of the programme (We are the ones turning, 2019) won the Verzasca Nera award. She has been dealing extensively with the topic of death and time consciousness in photography, often incorporating literary works into her practice. Following her thesis project, she self-published a book “As if you could kill time without injuring eternity…” where her photographs are presented in dialogue with the lines of Vladimir Nabokov. Aside from the artistic work, she has been exploring and documenting Blue zones (longevity hotspots) in a long-term collaboration with the writer and philosopher Jaka Gerčar.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h3>Related Links</h3>\n<p><a href=\"https://anazibelnik.format.com\">anazibelnik.format.com</a></p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p style=\"text-align: https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/1-1-9a517387-90b7-4c5e-be06-b2621d7730c2.jpg?w=2400&#38;ssl=1 2400w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\" /></h4>\n<h4>Mariia Ermolenko</h4>\n<h2>Flow</h2>\n<h5>[ FUJIFILM/YOUNG TALENT AWARD 2019 FINALIST ] </h5>\n<p>In my project I research time. Man is in perpetual search. In Japanese philosophy, there is the concept of &#8220;Fueki Riuko&#8221;. This is about form of the eternal and continuous, which are associated with the current and instant. These pictures were taken in different places that I visited. During travels, I take a very clear view of what is happening. And I do not want this to end. Life is fragile, and our stay in it is fleeting as a journey. My series is about the impression, about the moment, about life and death. Often, when my eyes are closed, memories pop up in my head. A person becomes a memoryless person. Memories are like a mosaic that constitutes man. As long as I remember, I am who I am. I&#8217;m afraid of losing memories. To forget is to die.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/2-2-2/'><img width=\"4000\" height=\"2948\" data-large-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/18-18-f2621cdd-aaa8-49e0-b238-07ddc8db45a0.jpg?fit=800%2C530&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h3>Short Bio</h3>\n<p>Mariia was born in St. Petersburg (Russia) in 1995. She studied at the restoration of painting. She studied painting with masters from the Academy of Arts. Now studying at the Academy of Documentary Photography. Mariia is interested in exploring the themes of memory, time, the boundaries between sleep and reality, the themes of myths, as well as themes of ecology and the state of the environment. Lives and works in St. Petersburg.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h3>Related Links</h3>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.mariiaermolenko.com\">mariiaermolenko.com</a></p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p style=\"text-align: efae94.webp","https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/18-18-f2621cdd-aaa8-49e0-b238-07ddc8db45a0.jpg?fit=3089%2C2048&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn44@2020_2/2020/08/25/01-16-31-277_11563354a3dd5a83.webp","https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/FujiFilm_Basic-Black-1.png?resize=100%2C86":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn44@2020_3/2020/08/25/01-16-24-066_1830dfe08ed7f9c8.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598318178429},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 /></h4>\n<h4 class=\"sc-jbKcbu ftkFFW\">Joel Pulliam</h4>\n</div>\n<h2>Springtime Nightmare</h2>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>I moved to Tokyo with my family in 2018. For nearly two years, life was happy. Then, without warning, my young daughter died.</p>\n<p>Can art begin to convey a father’s grief?  Over three hundred years ago, the haiku poet Raizan Konishi wrote after the loss of his own child:  </p>\n<p><i>I must be crazy</i></p>\n<p><i>to not be crazy in this</i></p>\n<p><i>crazy springtime nightmare</i></p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/05/joel-pulliam-springtime-nightmare/attachment/joel_pulliam_for_burn2100-5/'><img width=\"2100\" height=\"1400\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;4.8&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;X-Pro2&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1583798315&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;200&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;3200&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0.076923076923077&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;1&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"joel_pulliam_for_burn2100 &#8211; 13\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/joel_pulliam_for_burn2100-13.jpg?fit=600%2C800&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/joel_pulliam_for_burn2100-13.jpg?fit=768%2C1024&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>Springtime nightmare, indeed. Outside, the pandemic widens, and emergency orders quiet the city.  Snow falls out of season, blanketing the cherry blossoms. Human contact fades. The streets near my home, once so familiar, appear alien. I wander them, point my camera, and press the shutter. The only images I seem able to capture are those that reflect my own inner state.  </p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<div>\n<h3>Bio</h3>\n</div>\n<div>\n<p>Joel Pulliam was born in the United States in 1974.  He studied history and literature at Harvard College, then law at Harvard Law School.  Until 2018, he worked at the United States Department of the Treasury.  Currently, he lives in Tokyo, where his black-and-white photography of the city has been recognized by publications such as the <i>Asahi Shimbun</i> newspaper and <i>Asahi Camera</i> magazine.  His long-term projects center on various areas of Tokyo that have been neglected by other photographers.</p>\n</div>\n<div> </div>\n<div>\n<h3>Related Links</h3>\n<p><a href=\"http://joelpulliam.com\">joelpulliam.com</a></p>\n</div>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 17 May data-recalc-dims=\"1\" /></h4>\n<h4 class=\"sc-jbKcbu ftkFFW\">Ute Behrend</h4>\n</div>\n<h2>Bear Girls</h2>\n<h5>[ EPF 2019 FINALIST ]</h5>\n<p>How do young girls become strong women? Adolescence is the theme of my new book. At the beginning I tell a story about a fictional &#8220;Indian tribe&#8221; that separates its pubescent girls and dresses them in bearskins. In this way they are protected from premature sexualisation. The result is a shelter that gives the girls the opportunity to develop freely and self-determinedly in this important phase of their lives. I call these girls &#8220;bear girls&#8221; and draw parallels in our society, where free spaces for adolescent girls become less and less. Many young women try to evade the stereotypes of sexualised identification that are shaped by society and the media. This is often evident in similar behaviour patterns, e.g. wearing very large sweaters that girls like to &#8220;borrow&#8221; from their father&#8217;s wardrobe.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/02/ute-behrend-bear-girls/attachment/3-bear-girl-in-forest-bear-girl-in-bedroom-a5960149-b6ce-4774-bcf8-5fb5081c74a7-2/'><img width=\"2100\" height=\"1559\" src=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3-„Bear-Girl-in-forest-Bear-Girl-in-bedroom“-a5960149-b6ce-4774-bcf8-5fb5081c74a7.jpg?fit=2100%2C1559&#38;ssl=1\" https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3-„Bear-Girl-in-forest-Bear-Girl-in-bedroom“-a5960149-b6ce-4774-bcf8-5fb5081c74a7.jpg?resize=800%2C594&#38;ssl=1 800w, data-medium-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/12-“Bear-Fireworks”-82698a85-3047-459d-bf02-e047b68ca22e.jpg?fit=800%2C594&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/12-“Bear-Fireworks”-82698a85-3047-459d-bf02-e047b68ca22e.jpg?fit=800%2C594&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>In &#8220;Smart Girls, Gifted Women&#8221;, Barbara Kerr examined the similarities that later became strong women. She found that all girls had time for themselves, the ability to fall in love with an idea, and a &#8220;protective cover&#8221;. None was particularly popular and most remained relatively isolated in their age group. Interestingly, this rejection gave them a free space in which they could develop their uniqueness. Parallel to the portraits of the girls I take photographs with a focus on nature, wild animals and the concept of distance and closeness. I then work on combining these single images to final pairs. The references between the pictures are intended to stimulate the viewer to link the content of what he has seen. Out of one&#8217;s own memory and also out of cultural memory.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h3>Short Bio</h3>\n<div class=\"sc-RefOD kyWBYY\">\n<div class=\"sc-cqpYsc iCVdLz\">\n<p class=\"sc-fQejPQ gxlmwq Paragraph-sc-972wlj-0 cOTQqy\">Biografie 2019 Artist Book, Bear Girls, (artists‘ book) Publisher: BummBumm Books, Cologne, Germany 2015 Teaching assignment, Academy for Communication Design, Cologne, Germany 2011 The Last Year of Childhood (artists‘ book) Publisher: POWERSHOVEL.BOOKS, Tokio/New York 2009 The Door Behind the Wall | Project with handicapped and non-handicapped inhabitants of the Dr. Dormagen-Guffanti foundation, Cologne, Germany 2008 &#8211; 09 Teaching assignment, College of Higher Education Bielefeld, Germany 2008 Zimmerpflanzen (artists‘ book), publisher: Snoeck Verlag, Cologne, Germany 2007 Teaching assignment for Visual Communications Merz Akademie,Germany 2006 Mermaids, video Galerie 11, in the Gruner + Jahr publishing house, Hamburg, Germany 2005 Teaching assigment, College of Higher education Voralberg, Austria Märchen, Fairy Tales (artists‘ book) Publisher: Verlag der Buchhandlung Walter König, Cologne, Germany 2004 Observer and Indoor Plants (booklet) latent, aristotelean mimesis within the thriller genre | label: www.bold-dvd.de 2002 Art goes School | State Chancellery, Saarland, Germany 2001 kunstKöln special edition 1996 Girls, Some Boys and Other Cookies (artists‘ book) Publisher: Scalo Verlag, Zürich, Switzerland 1987-93 Academic studies: Photographic Design University of Applied Sciences and Arts, Dortmund, Germany 1985-87 Academic studies: Communication Design 1979-82 Apprenticeship as a carpenter</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n<aside class=\"sc-iQKALj lowtCN\">\n<div class=\"sc-bwCtUz jmIOcX\" title=\"Daniel Kovalovszky\"> </div>\n</aside>\n<h3>Related src=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/1.jpg?resize=800%2C562&#038;ssl=1\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"562\" srcset=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/1.jpg?w=1332&#38;ssl=1 1332w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/1.jpg?resize=170%2C119&#38;ssl=1 170w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/1.jpg?resize=800%2C562&#38;ssl=1 800w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/1.jpg?resize=768%2C539&#38;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/1.jpg?resize=1024%2C719&#38;ssl=1 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\" /></h4>\n<h4 class=\"sc-jbKcbu ftkFFW\">Luis Cobelo</h4>\n</div>\n<h2>Chas Chas</h2>\n<div><span style=\"color: #000000; font-family: arial, sans-serif;\">30 years ago, I came across a story in a comic book called &#8220;Parque Chas&#8221;, about a mysterious neighborhood in Buenos Aires, Argentina. The comic reveals the adventures of a writer who was told that fantastic and extraordinary things happen there. A place where wonderful mystical people live.</span></div>\n<div> </div>\n<div>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/01/luis-cobelo-chas-chas/attachment/2-8/'><img width=\"720\" src=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/11.jpg?fit=3384%2C2376&#38;ssl=1\" class=\"attachment-full size-full\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/11.jpg?w=3384&#38;ssl=1 3384w, https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/11.jpg?resize=170%2C119&#38;ssl=1 170w, https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/11.jpg?resize=800%2C562&#38;ssl=1 800w, https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/11.jpg?resize=768%2C539&#38;ssl=1 768w, https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/11.jpg?resize=1024%2C719&#38;ssl=1 1024w, https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/11.jpg?w=1600&#38;ssl=1 1600w, https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/11.jpg?w=2400&#38;ssl=1 2400w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" data-attachment-id=\"68391\" data-permalink=\"https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/01/luis-cobelo-chas-chas/attachment/11-16/\" data-orig-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/11.jpg?fit=3384%2C2376&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"3384,2376\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;1&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"11\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/11.jpg?fit=800%2C562&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/11.jpg?fit=800%2C562&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n</div>\n<div> </div>\n<div><span style=\"color: #000000; font-family: arial, sans-serif;\"> </span></div>\n<div><span style=\"color: #000000; font-family: arial, sans-serif;\">The reason such unusual things can take place there is because the center of the neighborhood was architecturally constructed similar to a spiderweb or a labyrinth. That&#8217;s why they say (the &#8216;chas chasians&#8217;) that if you enter into that concentric form, you may never leave, and magical things can happen to you. Many say that this is the true reality. Essentially, in Parque Chas everything is possible.</span></div>\n<div> </div>\n<div> </div>\n<div>\n\n<a data-image-title=\"21\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/21.jpg?fit=533%2C800&#38;ssl=1\" sans-serif;\"> </span></div>\n<div><span style=\"color: #000000; font-family: arial, sans-serif;\">All these years later, I decided to travel thousands of kilometers to see for myself. But what really led me there was to discover if there was truth in their claim: &#8220;Everything you ever lost in your life, exists in Parque Chas&#8221;. And yes, I found it.</span></div>\n<div> </div>\n<div><span style=\"color: #000000; font-family: arial, sans-serif;\">The project &#8220;Chas Chas&#8221; is an intangible exploration of the intricate myths and amazing lives of this neighborhood.</span></div>\n<div> </div>\n<div>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/01/luis-cobelo-chas-chas/attachment/portada_chas_chas-copy-2/'><img data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;Portada_Chas_Chas data-medium-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/contraportada.jpg?fit=569%2C800&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/contraportada.jpg?fit=665%2C935&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n</div>\n<div> </div>\n<div> </div>\n<div>\n<h3>Short Bio</h3>\n</div>\n<div> </div>\n<div>Born in Venezuela, Luis Cobelo took his philosophical studies as a warm coat to Galicia, Spain, where his family&#8217;s roots grew. Working independently across borders, Luis develops documentary projects in America, Asia and Europe, and has been published in many magazines and newspapers. His Latino soul brings him back to South America very often, where he created his first book &#8220;Zurumbático” and “Chas Chas”,  (both self-published) <wbr />to reveal the magical spirit of this part of the world.  “Zurumbático” book has fascinated people all over the world and the exhibition of this work has traveled across oceans: Italy, México, Miami, Madrid, Costa Rica, Portugal and Venezuela. Now, he’s presenting “Chas Chas” the second second part of a collection of fantasies, mysteries and magical stories of the Latin American continent. </div>\n<div> </div>\n<div>\n<h3>Related https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1-ParlamentiPantanella_ATLAS_Burn01-6a2f89cd-a00a-429d-aa21-e8073a8052b5.jpg?w=2400&#38;ssl=1 2400w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\" /></h4>\n<h4 class=\"sc-jbKcbu ftkFFW\">Lavinia Parlamenti &#38; Manfredi Pantanella</h4>\n</div>\n<h2>An Atlas of Countries that Don&#8217;t Exist</h2>\n<h5>[ EPF 2019 FINALIST ]</h5>\n<p>Political charts of the world are very fluid realities. Countries are created and countries die. In today’s world, globalization hasn’t killed the concept of Nation-State, but has certainly tore down its importance. A world once defined by borders and supervised by the static power of national governments, has been replaced by a more dynamic kind of transnational reality, in which the power is no longer connected to a single State, but takes the form of NGOs, banks and societies who rule by collecting global data. In this ever-changing scenario, little attention is paid to the fact that the map of the world is still hiding today a huge number of unrecognized States.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2019/12/lavinia-parlamenti-manfredi-pantanella-an-atlas-of-countries-that-dont-exist/attachment/2-parlamentipantanella_atlas_burn02-1a16cdaf-3923-49b6-9fb1-54c29c0289e8_1/'><img data-permalink=\"https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2019/12/lavinia-parlamenti-manfredi-pantanella-an-atlas-of-countries-that-dont-exist/attachment/11-parlamentipantanella_atlas_burn11-88acc597-2b3b-4cb4-bebc-e6be54d7c0f0/\" data-orig-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11-ParlamentiPantanella_Atlas_Burn11-88acc597-2b3b-4cb4-bebc-e6be54d7c0f0.jpg?fit=2000%2C3000&#38;ssl=1\" data-orig-size=\"2000,3000\" data-comments-opened=\"0\" data-image-meta=\"{&#34;aperture&#34;:&#34;11&#34;,&#34;credit&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;camera&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;caption&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;created_timestamp&#34;:&#34;1538435352&#34;,&#34;copyright&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;focal_length&#34;:&#34;40&#34;,&#34;iso&#34;:&#34;1250&#34;,&#34;shutter_speed&#34;:&#34;0.0125&#34;,&#34;title&#34;:&#34;&#34;,&#34;orientation&#34;:&#34;1&#34;}\" data-image-title=\"11 &#8211; ParlamentiPantanella_Atlas_Burn11 &#8211; 88acc597-2b3b-4cb4-bebc-e6be54d7c0f0\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11-ParlamentiPantanella_Atlas_Burn11-88acc597-2b3b-4cb4-bebc-e6be54d7c0f0.jpg?fit=533%2C800&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11-ParlamentiPantanella_Atlas_Burn11-88acc597-2b3b-4cb4-bebc-e6be54d7c0f0.jpg?fit=683%2C1024&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>Our “Atlas of Countries that Don’t Exist” is an imaginary journey in real territories that uses documentary photography to show the paradox of those portions of the world that self-declared their independence but &#8211; for different reasons &#8211; haven’t been recognized by the UN. By documenting and conceptualizing some aspects of the reality of these places,our work in progress aims at stimulating a reflection on the subject of personal and national identity, at a time in which this seems to us more than necessary. The physical place where one is born, where one is guarded after death, the family; these are elements defining our personal identity. On the other hand, the culture of a place (arts, monuments, traditions, food), its history and politics, the fauna and the flora, make up the identity of a “Nation”. That’s why we are dealing with tracing these elements in the 12 territories we have chosen to portray: Transnistria, North Cyprus, Catalunya, Republic of Artsakh, Isle of Man, Iraqi Kurdistan, Greenland, Somaliland, Sahrawi, Lakota, Taiwan and Ryukyu. Having already visited the first 3 territories, the Burn Emerging Fund would allow to carry on our research including the maximum variety of global situations into the Atlas, which we hope will take the form of a book and an interactive exhibition.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2019/12/lavinia-parlamenti-manfredi-pantanella-an-atlas-of-countries-that-dont-exist/attachment/12-parlamentipantanella_atlas_burn12-ab063f7d-39cb-403f-a06b-d06b2adae907/'><img width=\"3508\" height=\"2480\" src=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/12-ParlamentiPantanella_Atlas_Burn12-ab063f7d-39cb-403f-a06b-d06b2adae907.jpg?fit=3508%2C2480&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/25-ParlamentiPantanella_Atlas_Burn25-7f1f3330-1369-4232-a645-dbe9536f6a36.jpg?fit=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h3>Short Bio</h3>\n<div class=\"sc-RefOD kyWBYY\">\n<div class=\"sc-cqpYsc iCVdLz\">\n<p class=\"sc-fQejPQ gxlmwq Paragraph-sc-972wlj-0 cOTQqy\">Lavinia Parlamenti and Manfredi Pantanella met each other in Tahrir Square at the end of 2011, during the second wave of the so called Egyptian Revolution. Their collective research mainly focuses on geopolitical paradoxes and aims to combine documentary photography with the dimension of surreal and fantastic. Meeting point of their different personalities is, with no doubts, a common ironical approach to life (therefore to photography) and the great value that they give to imagination inside reality. Their first collective project, “Roundabout#Cyprus” (2012), has been transformed into a book and self-published in 2013. In the last years, Lavinia and Manfredi also realized several editorial works in Italy, Europe and the Middle East, collaborating with newspapers and magazines as LaRepubblica, Le Monde, The New York Times, Time, Internazionale, IoDonna, Vanity Fair, Panenka football magazine.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n<aside class=\"sc-iQKALj lowtCN\">\n<div class=\"sc-bwCtUz jmIOcX\" title=\"Daniel Kovalovszky\"> </div>\n</aside>\n<h3>Related Links</h3>\n<p><a href=\"http://www.laviniaparlamenti.com\">www.laviniaparlamenti.com</a></p>\n<p><a 800px\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\" /></h4>\n<h4 class=\"sc-jbKcbu ftkFFW\">Sathish Kumar</h4>\n</div>\n<h2>Town Boy</h2>\n<h5>[ EPF 2019 FINALIST ]</h5>\n<p>These are images from as early as my teens to this day. The essence of every new experience as I was growing up was recorded with my camera &#8211; roaming around the neighborhood, meeting old friends, most times making new ones. At some point, I had to move to a large city for work. As the life in a large city got suffocating, I began to seek relief by going back to my town or by going on treks, to take a deep breath, to be back to the demands of the city. Town Boy is an observation of this gradual transformation into who I am today. These string of images are about my coming of age, my movement from a small town to a cosmopolitan city, to somehow fit into this contemporary world. (ongoing work)</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2019/12/sathish-kumar-town-boy/attachment/2-town-boy_sathish-kumar_02-8a86ee30-fe29-4982-9bd1-5405b261cc11/'><img data-large-file=\"https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/25-Town-Boy_Sathish-Kumar_25-a96ad277-a7a8-4016-846d-a64ad01083b9.jpg?fit=800%2C533&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h3>Short Bio</h3>\n<div class=\"sc-RefOD kyWBYY\">\n<div class=\"sc-cqpYsc iCVdLz\">\n<p class=\"sc-fQejPQ gxlmwq Paragraph-sc-972wlj-0 cOTQqy\">Sathish Kumar, born in 1986 in Kanchipuram, India. A large part of my school vacations was spent at my uncle’s photo studio which became an inspiration for me to pursue photography. I got a point and shoot film camera from my uncle as a gift which I always carried around to school picnics, cricket grounds shooting my friends and everything around. With photography, I want to record my everyday existence, of all encounters and journeys to create an expression of myself, of my life, of the world around. Currently, I am working as a freelance photographer and as an artist pursuing personal works from Chennai, India.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n<aside class=\"sc-iQKALj lowtCN\">\n<div class=\"sc-bwCtUz jmIOcX\" title=\"Daniel Kovalovszky\"> </div>\n</aside>\n<h3>Related Links</h3>\n<p><a href=\"http://sathishphoto.com\">sathishphoto.com</a></p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">&#8212;&#8211;</p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"> </p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">The Emerging Photographer Fund is supported by generous donors to the Magnum 8_f1c244ff23726319.webp","https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/24-Town-Boy_Sathish-Kumar_24-8eac8cb9-a1d1-4bd9-92da-786e55207dd8.jpg?fit=3000%2C2000&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn99@2020_5/2020/08/25/01-16-36-545_6a9b058e7b5fd62a.webp","https://i0.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/25-Town-Boy_Sathish-Kumar_25-a96ad277-a7a8-4016-846d-a64ad01083b9.jpg?fit=3000%2C1999&ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn23@2020_1/2020/08/25/01-16-29-063_bce9a9abe2e642cc.webp","https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/magnumfoundation.png?resize=202%2C82":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn91@2020_3/2020/08/25/01-16-34-378_f5de62f6d0112576.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598318178431},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 data-recalc-dims=\"1\" /></h4>\n<h4>Anniina Joensalo</h4>\n<h2>Tender</h2>\n<h5>[ FUJIFILM/YOUNG TALENT AWARD 2019 FINALIST ] </h5>\n<p>“Tender” is an exploration into the contradictions inherent in queer lives and loves. I want to explore all aspects of intimacy in a non-normative way and in non-normative settings. In this series I’ve captured the people around me, my friends, partners and lovers. I’m inspired by the space queer people take up everyday, and the work they undertake in love and friendship. I am compelled to get as close to people as possible. My objective was to portray power balances between subject and photographer, to show the juxtaposition of tenderness and violence. “Tender” aims to bring up questions of intimacy and consent within these queer relationships where individuals are often pushing the boundaries of love and sex in anarchic ways.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/01/anniina-joensalo-tender/attachment/2-finally-c8741d1f-856d-4b5b-8d80-7208334e3bef-2/'><img width=\"1576\" height=\"2100\" data-image-title=\"8 &#8211; Forest Animal in Ferbruary &#8211; 14aeccaf-a323-4e33-8c92-0b700183e88e\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/8-Forest-Animal-in-Ferbruary-14aeccaf-a323-4e33-8c92-0b700183e88e.jpg?fit=600%2C800&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i2.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/8-Forest-Animal-in-Ferbruary-14aeccaf-a323-4e33-8c92-0b700183e88e.jpg?fit=768%2C1024&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>Queer people are often subject to violences in their early lives, forced to fight for an identity and to push against binaries. Often through these hardships they become more in touch with their narratives and their needs. Their paths are sometimes beautiful, sometimes sad. Usually consisting of polarizing extremities, from anxiety to pure bliss. What lies between these tensions is calmness; a moment of reaching peaceful intimacy with another after a long wait of uncertainty. These moments of tenderness are full of power, where queer expression is encouraged and accepted. These are portraits of queerness I want to showcase.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n\n<a href='https://www.burnmagazine.org/essays/2020/01/anniina-joensalo-tender/attachment/9-thank-you-i-73b1dabd-2b36-424f-abf7-43db1989ba17-2/'><img width=\"1750\" height=\"2100\" data-image-title=\"18 &#8211; Oily &#8211; 47c12c2e-c4a3-48d2-841b-537f0c5944fa\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/18-Oily-47c12c2e-c4a3-48d2-841b-537f0c5944fa.jpg?fit=626%2C800&#38;ssl=1\" data-large-file=\"https://i1.wp.com/www.burnmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/18-Oily-47c12c2e-c4a3-48d2-841b-537f0c5944fa.jpg?fit=800%2C1021&#38;ssl=1\" /></a>\n\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h3>Short Bio</h3>\n<p>Careers like a photographer didn’t exist where I grew up. The world around me and the people in it were executing a perfect working class life of teachers, nurses, and factory workers. I was watching them in awe: they were on autopilot; blissfully unaware. Go to school, find a boy, get married, have a nice house and kids. This was the narrative I was given and it was supported by all the stories I was exposed to. In the abundance of visual storytelling my responsibility as an artist is to give emphasis to the meaningful ones. I should find and bring out the stories that wouldn’t be heard otherwise, to this audience that wouldn&#8217;t be exposed to them. My mission as a photographer is exploring stories in which the identities of different kinds of people are represented. My objective is to explore and portray a lifestyle outside of the patriarchal, capitalist and heteronormative structures of couples, romance and religious norms. I want our identity to be represented to the future queer generation growing up. I want our love stories. This “Queer Way of Living” is my own personal utopia that I chose to believe in.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<h3>Related Links</h3>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.anniinajoensalo.com\">anniinajoensalo.com</a></p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">&#8212;&#8211;</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">The
